end.title: Dead End Drive-In
end.creator_credit: Andrew Williams and Roger Cowland
end.brief_description: In the near future, drive-in theatres are turned into concentration camps for the undesirable and unemployed. The prisoners don’t really care to escape because they are fed and they have a place to live which is, in most cases, probably better than the outside. Crabs and his girlfriend Carmen are put into the camp and all Crabs wants to do is escape.

end.title: Drive-In Horror
end.credit_line:
Edie Kurzer, Australia 2020

Drive-in cinema blueprint

Courtesy of David Kilderry, Lunar Drive-In Dandenong
end.brief_description: Sweeping Australia in the 1950s and based on the American model, the drive-in cinema became one of the country’s most popular theatrical experiences. Capitalising on the communal experience and outdoor environment, genre films – and horror in particular – thrived in this format. Australia’s first drive-in cinema, the Skyline, opened in Burwood, Melbourne in 1954, followed by the Lunar Drive-In in Dandenong in 1956, which is still operating. At the peak of their popularity, there were over 330 drive-ins across the country, before a downturn in the 1980s. Their place in popular culture was cemented when Ozploitation director Brian Trenchard-Smith used one as his futuristic prison in dystopian horror film Dead End Drive-In in 1986.

end.title: First Screening: Computer Poems
end.brief_description: A suite of a dozen kinetic poems programmed in Apple BASIC. Later, as the first versions became inaccessible, the works were recreated in HyperCard in the early 1990s (after bpNichol’s death), and then in 2007 recreated in javascript for the web, and simultaneously the original BASIC and Hypercard files were republished for download.

end.title: Fraggle Rock
end.creator_credit: Jerry Juhl, Jim Henson, CBC and Henson Associates, Inc.
end.brief_description: The Fraggles are a fun-loving community of creatures who live in a subterranean fantasy land where they love to play, sing and dance their cares away, sharing their world with the tiny Doozers and the giant Gorgs. The series teaches empathy and tolerance and encourages children to understand people different from themselves.

results.name: Joy of drag
results.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

key_work.title: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert
key_work.creator_credit: Stephan Elliott, Al Clark, Michael Hamlyn, Latent Image and Specific Films
key_work.brief_description: When drag queen Anthony (Hugo Weaving) takes his act on the road with fellow cross-dresser Adam (Guy Pearce) and transsexual Bernadette (Terence Stamp). In their colorful bus, Priscilla, the three performers travel across the Australian desert performing for enthusiastic crowds and homophobic locals.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

constellations_other.name: Dance sequins
constellations_other.description: Looking at dance, ballroom, the Glitter Trilogy and the Red Curtain Trilogy.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

recommendations.quote: The film's three leads have all swapped fabulous frocks for villainous outfits in superhero films. Terrance Stamp was Zod in Superman 2, Hugo Weaving was Red Skull in Captain America: The First Avenger and Guy Pearce was Aldrich Killian in Iron Man 3.

results.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers
results.description: Multiple characters and doubles materialise in this Constellation inspired by the pioneering special effects of Georges Méliès.

key_work.title: Georges Méliès in Un homme de têtes (The Four Troublesome Heads)
key_work.brief_description: Georges Méliès was truly a magician of the screen. It’s no surprise, considering he enchanted people as an illusionist before devising many special effects and film techniques. At the turn of the 21st century he created seamless screen illusions through in-camera tricks.

end.brief_description: The Play House is a 1921 American two-reel silent comedy film written, directed by, and starring Buster Keaton. The movie runs for 22 minutes, and is most famous for an opening sequence in which Keaton plays every role.

constellations_other.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers

links.description: Pioneering filmmaker Georges Méliès used multiple exposures to create the special effect of multiple, floating heads. Likewise, American filmmaker Buster Keaton used camera tricks and techniques to multiply himself in The Playhouse.

video_links.name: The Matrix - 20th Anniversary - Warner Bros. UK

start.brief_description: Set in the 22nd century, The Matrix tells the story of a computer hacker who joins a group of underground insurgents fighting the vast and powerful computers who now rule the earth.

constellations_other.name: Hard sci-fi to cyberpunk
constellations_other.description: Ayoung Kim's practice has been inspired by 'hard' science fiction writers like Greg Egan. Recent sci-fi media using hard sci-fi can be connected back to the beginnings of cyberpunk, a sub-genre of sci-fi.

constellations_other.name: Directions of storytelling
constellations_other.description: Panoramic slides gave magic lanternists the ability to progress narratives by adjusting slides left or right. This movement is emblematic of a panning shot where the camera follows the action the natural way your head moves.

constellations_other.name: Clones, doubles and doppelgangers

constellations_other.name: Sci-fi miniatures
constellations_other.description: As filmmaking technologies have changed and evolved over the decades, much like audiences, miniatures have endured as one of the most effective film special effects.

links.description: The Matrix borrows heavily from Hong Kong martial arts films like Twin Dragons, where special effects let Jackie Chan play identical twins.

Leaving a trail of admirers in her wake, our thoroughly modern heroine makes sure she enjoys every moment of her lucky life.

links.description: L.A. Noire has been criticised for its lack of female representation. Miss Fisher’s Murder Mysteries wouldn’t face the same accusation and inverts many film noir tropes to celebrate an independently wealthy, female private detective.

links.description: The success of early horror films inspired the strange angles and shadows common in German Expressionism to be adopted by film noir to portray a pessimistic world bristling with crime, anti-heroes and femme fatales. John Huston’s The Maltese Falcon is considered a landmark early work in the genre.

key_work.title: House of Wax
key_work.brief_description: House of Wax was the first colour 3D feature film that incorporated stereo sround. So not only did action spring from the screen, but sound effects were also heard in different sections of the cinema, heightening the drama through the illusion of multi-directional audio.

end.title: Memoir of a Snail – Storyboards
end.creator_credit: Adam Elliot
end.brief_description: Academy Award® winner Adam Elliot oversees an enormous amount of work to bring his stop-motion films to life. Over five months during Melbourne’s COVID-19 lockdowns, Elliot drew 1600 storyboards, some of which you can see here. Storyboards help directors visualise the story and camera movement before shooting begins, creating a blueprint for filming. Alongside these, he also drew 200 characters, 200 sets and thousands of props, which were later handmade by a team of artists over a year. From the storyboards, a rough animation called an animatic was made, which provided a guide for each shot of the film. There’s not a single frame of CGI (computer-generated imagery) in Memoir of a Snail (2024), which took over 33 weeks and 135,000 photographs to shoot.

links.description: While computers can make stop-motion animation easier, Oscar-winner Adam Elliot still does everything by hand, using traditional stop-motion and filmmaking techniques, from storyboarding to shooting individual photos to animate scenes.

end.title: Valkyrie costume with sword, sheath and daggers
end.brief_description:
Like Thor, Tessa Thompson’s King Valkyrie had plenty of costume changes throughout Thor: Love and Thunder. Her hero armour has been adapted to fit the bolder, more 80s look of the latest film, with stark, armoured panels of black and white.
Thompson loved the variety of looks for Valkyrie. “I love a costume change,” she said. “You get to see Valkyrie in these suited kingly looks, and then you get to see her in her pyjamas, which I love. Because when have you ever seen a superhero in pyjamas? Even heroes go to sleep.”
She continued: “I think that’s what’s really exciting about these films, in general, is to see the way in which characters evolve.”

links.description: One of the most visually stunning (and heartbreaking) scenes in Thor: Ragnarok details the demise of the Asgardian Valkyries against Hela. The last Valkyrie (Tessa Thompson) appears again in Thor: Love and Thunder atop a pegasus.

results.name: Colour and creativity
results.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

key_work.title: Hand-coloured film
key_work.brief_description: It’s estimated that about 80% of films made between the 1890s and the 1920s were coloured through tinting, toning, stencilling and hand-colouring. This process helped bring vibrancy and beauty to fluttering butterfly wings, hypnotic dances and much more.

constellations_primary.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_primary.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

start.title: Metamorphosis of a Butterfly
start.brief_description: Metamorphoses du papillon is a two minute 1904 film directed by French filmmaker Gaston Velle. It features early special effects, elaborate costumes and hypnotic dances that show a caterpillar transforming into a butterfly.

constellations_other.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_other.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

end.title: Fiddlesticks
end.brief_description: Fiddlesticks is a groundbreaking 1930 animated cartoon film. It is the first complete sound cartoon to be photographed in two-strip Technicolor, and was also Ub Iwerks’s first cartoon since he departed from Walt Disney’s studio.

constellations_other.name: Colour and creativity
constellations_other.description: From dying film to Technicolor and beyond, creative applications of colour have been part of cinema since its inception.

links.description: Metamorphoses du Papillon is a hand-coloured ‘trick’ film that used the early colour method of dying important objects in the frame. Almost 30 years later, Fiddlesticks used the more advanced two-strip Technicolor process to produce the first colour cartoon.

links.description: The three-strip Technicolor process replaced the two-strip process and became popular in Hollywood during the 1930s. The Wizard of Oz (1939) was one of the most successful and iconic films to use Technicolor.

constellations_other.description: The Toupie Fantoche relies on four prismatic mirrors to reflect changes in animation states.

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

recommendations.quote: De Niro’s Travis Bickle is one of the key figures of American cinema; the passage of his taxi through the grubby, smoky streets of the city – accompanied by the great composer Bernard Herrmann’s final score – are unforgettable.  So are his improvised monologues - "Are you talking to me?”

links.description: Unlike highly saturated colours in The Wizard of Oz, Martin Scorsese de-saturated colour in Taxi Driver, particularly the brightly coloured blood, making it less prominent in order to get an “R” classification.

links.description: Manipulating colour lends symbolism to Schindler’s List. The film was shot on black-and-white except for sequences featuring a little girl in a red dress, which was shot in colour and then de-saturated, and represents the innocence of the Jewish people.

results.name: Sound and Hollywood
results.description: The impact of sound on Tinsel Town stretches from the beginning of cinema to recent award-winners, as well as the biggest band in K-Pop.

key_work.title: Vitaphone discs
key_work.brief_description: When Western Electric developed the Vitaphone for Warner Brothers, it changed movies forever. Early filmmakers experimented with sound but couldn’t match it perfectly with motion pictures. The Vitaphone solved that, creating synchronised playback through a vinyl disc manually linked to a film projector.

constellations_primary.name: Sound and Hollywood
constellations_primary.description: The impact of sound on Tinsel Town stretches from the beginning of cinema to recent award-winners, as well as the biggest band in K-Pop.

start.title: Don Juan
start.creator_credit: Alan Crosland
start.brief_description: Don Juan is a 1926 American romantic adventure film directed by Alan Crosland and starring John Barrymore. It is the first feature-length film to utilise the Vitaphone sound-on-disc sound system with a synchronised musical score and sound effects, though it has no spoken dialogue.

constellations_other.name: Sound and Hollywood

end.title: The Jazz Singer
end.creator_credit: Alan Crosland and Darryl F. Zanuck
end.brief_description: The Jazz Singer is a 1927 American musical drama film directed by Alan Crosland. It is the first feature-length motion picture with not only a synchronised recorded music score but also lip-synchronous singing and speech in several isolated sequences.

constellations_other.name: Oh, no! Beta!
constellations_other.description: The Sony Betacam BVP-3P was a broadcast-quality camera that used Sony's Beta system, most commonly found in consumer cameras. During the Format Wars in the 1970s and 80s, Beta lost to the cheaper and more accessible Video Home System (VHS).

constellations_other.name: Sound and Hollywood
constellations_other.description: The impact of sound on Tinsel Town stretches from the beginning of cinema to recent award-winners, as well as the biggest band in K-Pop.

links.description: The Jazz Singer not only featured synched music and sound effects, but the first recorded dialogue, with Al Jolson improvising many of the film’s lines, including ‘You ain’t heard nothing yet!’, which seemed quite fitting for the groundbreaking film.
